intro: Adenocaulon himalaicum, commonly known as the Himalayan dwarf bellflower, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of the Himalayas. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves and small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale blue. The plant typically thrives in high-altitude environments, often growing in rocky or alpine soils. Its botanical features include hairy stems and leaves, which help it retain moisture in its cold, arid habitat. Adenocaulon himalaicum is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens that mimic its natural environment.
